pullRequest.body:
This shows with minimal requirements on `R`, that the `R`-module `R[X]` is not finite, or if `R` is a field, that equivalently `R[X]` is infinite-dimensional. On the way, some theorems are proven on how the `R`-span of a set of polynomials in `R[X]` interacts with the degree of the elements, and that the span of finitely many polynomials is always contained in some `Polynomial.degreeLE n` and some `Polynomial.degreeLT n`.


---

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7239825119/job/19722138320)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7239825119/job/19722138365)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7239825119/job/19722138275)

```suggestion
theorem polynomial_not_module_finite {R : Type u} [Semiring R] [Nontrivial R] :
```

The direct proof is shorter:
```suggestion
   rcases degree_span' s_fin s_emp with p', _, hp'max
    exact natDegree p', fun p hp => mem_degreeLE.mpr ((hp'max _ hp).trans degree_le_natDegree)
```

I wonder if it's possible to deduce this from [Polynomial.basisMonomials](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/MvPolynomial/Basic.html#Polynomial.basisMonomials), but that currently only works for `CommSemiringR`, and I don't know how difficult it would be to generalize. So no need to do anything in this PR.

I've also noticed that if you allow for stronger assumptions like `R` being a field, you can pretty swiftly get that `R[X]` has countable dimension by using the work from the MvPolynomial module, e.g. [rank_mvPolynomial](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/MvPolynomial.html#MvPolynomial.rank_mvPolynomial). But without at least `CommSemiring R`, I agree not much more can be done. Thanks for the review!

With the current placement this lemma is in the namespace `Ideal`. Is that what you intended? I think I would have moved it up to the other lemmas and called it `not_finite`, so that the full name is `Polynomial.not_finite`. What do you think?
Yeah, admittedly I struggled a bit placing this lemma in a meaningful place. But I agree with your suggestion, I will move this around & rename.

```suggestion
  rcases span_of_finite_le_degreeLE s_fin with n, _
  exact n + 1, by rwa [degreeLT_eq_degreeLE]
```
The current name is probably fine, but `degreeLT_succ` or `degreeLT_succ_eq_degreeLE` might be better.
By the [naming convention](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html), this should be called `span_le_degreeLE` or `span_le_degreeLE_of_finite`. Similar for the lemma below.
You resolved this conversation without replying to my comment or addressing it. Did you forget to push your changes?
Apologies! Must have missed this one, I thought I had changed it. Thank you!

This name is quite low on information. I would prefer something like `degree_le_of_mem_span` or even `exists_degree_le_of_mem_span`. For `degree_span'`, I would append `of_finite` instead of an apostrophe.

```suggestion
/-- For every polynomial `p` in the span of a set `s : Set R[X]`, there exists a polynomial of `p'  s`
```

```suggestion
/-- A stronger version of `degree_span` under the assumption that the set `s : Set R[X]` is finite.
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/Polynomial/Basic): add thms on degree of span and non-finiteness of polynomial ring as module
